reference.title: Typewriter Maintenance Materials
reference.shortdesc: Using the proper materials to maintain a typewriter is essential to preserve its functionality and prevent damage to fragile mechanical components.

entry.p: Used to scrape ink or stuck-on residue from non-delicate typewriter components, such as the type slugs. Toothpicks can be used as an alternative.
Used to apply mineral spirits and clean hard-to-reach typewriter components.
Used to dissolve grease and hardened oils from internal mechanisms.
Used to remove loose dust, dirt, and lint from exterior surfaces and type keys.
Used to gently scrub ink and buildup from type slugs.
Used to remove dust and dirt from intricate and delicate mechanical components.
Used to wipe down exterior surfaces without leaving lint in greased/waxed components.
Used to clean ink buildup from metal key levers and type slugs.
Used to gently clean typewriter exterior and casing.
Used to protect skin from harsh mineral spirits, rubbing alcohol, ink, and lubricants.
Used to precisely apply cleaning solvents to hard-to-reach typewriter components.
Used to protect work surfaces from harsh cleaning chemicals, such as mineral spirits or lacquer thinner. Paper towels or microfiber towels can be layered as an alternative.
Used to evenly distribute cleaning solvents to metal typewriter components, such as the segment.
Used to aid in the drying of typewriter components and casing. Alternatively, a fan can be used.
Necessary when using harsh solvents or waxes that could cause respiratory distress.
Apply to moving components that would otherwise be damaged by lubricants that can harden or congeal over time. Sewing machine oil, gun oil, or a specialized typewriter oil is preferred.
Used to precisely apply oil to pivot points and hard-to-reach grooves while avoiding areas that could be damaged or dirtied by excessive oil. Alternatively, a medicine dropper can be used.
To help loosen and free stuck mechanical components. Excess oil should always be removed.
Protect typewriter from long-term dust and dirt buildup.
Protect exterior paint finish and prevent rusting of metal components.
Used when typewriter is in long-term storage to prevent excessive moisture buildup and rusting of mechanical components.
Using an appropriately thick sheet behind typing paper absorbs impact from type slugs and protects the platen from long term wear and tear.
Also known as a hex wrench, used to disassemble the mainspring housing. Size required will vary based on past typewriter repairs or replacement components.
Thick work glasses, such as construction glasses, are necessary when handling springs as they can pop out and cut skin/eyes without warning.
Used to repair typewriter rollers that need increased grip or thick debris removal. 400-600 grit is preferred.
Used to adhere new plastic tubing to an existing, damaged platen roller for quick repair.
Used to cover an existing platen roller that needs a new rubber surface.
Used to remove long-term staining, such as tobacco tar staining, on high-touch typewriter components. 3% is preferred.
A fresh ink ribbon will be required for replacement when print quality becomes deteriorated.
Strong solvent used to clean rubber rollers quickly. Ideal due to its ability to quickly dissolve oil and debris, while drying quickly and leaving no residue on rubber components.
Used to grab onto broken or loosened drawbands through the typewriter carriage.
Used in replacement or repair of a damaged or broken mainspring.
Various typewriter mechanics rely on springs to function and need to be replaced if they become worn or damaged.
Required to reach and handle small or dangerous components, such as the drawband hooks or mainspring.
If platen or feeder rollers harden or become cracked, they cannot be repaired and must be replaced.
The disassembly and reassembly process will require many phillips and flat head screwdrivers of various sizes.
Some components of a typewriter, particularly the mainspring, are dangerous and can easily cut skin.
